content.raw:
Various observations:

---

I'm seeing the `log.zip` file being created even if I'm not recording resources. Is this expected?

---

I also noticed that if I run the `log_record_resources` world twice in a row I get these messages:

```
[Err] [Zip.cc:42] Error adding directory to zip: /tmp/log
[Err] [Zip.cc:103] Error compressing file: /tmp/log
[Err] [LogRecord.cc:534] Failed to compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log.zip]
```

If I remember correctly, we were creating new numbered directories if the directory already existed?

---

The `zip` file is created as a sibling to the record path, i.e.:

```
/tmp/log
|-- home
|   `-- chapulina
|-- server_console.log
`-- state.tlog
/tmp/log.zip
```

This was a bit counter-intuitive to me, because I was expecting Gazebo not to create any files outside that directory. But maybe it's just me.

Also, keeping both the zip file and the original folders means every log takes even more space, with redundant information. Some things I'm wondering about:

* Should we delete the directory after zipping it?

* Should we make zipping optional?

* Should we support playing back directly from the zip file?

---

I think we more fixes to the paths are needed. Try this:

1. `ign gazebo -v 4 -r log_record_resources.sdf --record-resources --record-path '/tmp/log'`
1. `rm -rf ~/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area`
1. `ign gazebo --force-version 2.9.0 -v 4 -r log_playback.sdf`

Instead of loading the logged mesh, the simulation prints these errors:

```
[GUI] [Err] [SystemPaths.cc:434] File [file:///home/chapulina/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area/2//meshes/Asphalt_Plane.DAE] resolved to path [/home/chapulina/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area/2//meshes/Asphalt_Plane.DAE] but the path does not exist
[GUI] [Err] [MeshManager.cc:172] Unable to find file[file:///home/chapulina/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area/2//meshes/Asphalt_Plane.DAE]
[GUI] [Err] [MeshDescriptor.cc:56] Mesh manager can't find mesh named [file:///home/chapulina/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area/2//meshes/Asphalt_Plane.DAE]
[GUI] [Err] [Ogre2MeshFactory.cc:430] Cannot load null mesh [file:///home/chapulina/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area/2//meshes/Asphalt_Plane.DAE]
[GUI] [Err] [Ogre2MeshFactory.cc:72] Failed to get Ogre item for [file:///home/chapulina/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area/2//meshes/Asphalt_Plane.DAE]
[GUI] [Err] [SceneManager.cc:271] Failed to load geometry for visual: plane_visual
[GUI] [Err] [SystemPaths.cc:434] File [file:///home/chapulina/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area/2//meshes/Entrance.obj] resolved to path [/home/chapulina/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area/2//meshes/Entrance.obj] but the path does not exist
[GUI] [Err] [MeshManager.cc:172] Unable to find file[file:///home/chapulina/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area/2//meshes/Entrance.obj]
[GUI] [Err] [MeshDescriptor.cc:56] Mesh manager can't find mesh named [file:///home/chapulina/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area/2//meshes/Entrance.obj]
[GUI] [Err] [Ogre2MeshFactory.cc:430] Cannot load null mesh [file:///home/chapulina/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area/2//meshes/Entrance.obj]
[GUI] [Err] [Ogre2MeshFactory.cc:72] Failed to get Ogre item for [file:///home/chapulina/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/models/subt_tunnel_staging_area/2//meshes/Entrance.obj]
[GUI] [Err] [SceneManager.cc:271] Failed to load geometry for visual: visual
```

Various observations:

I'm seeing the log.zip file being created even if I'm not recording resources. Is this expected?

I also noticed that if I run the log_record_resources world twice in a row I get these messages:

[Err] [Zip.cc:42] Error adding directory to zip: /tmp/log
[Err] [Zip.cc:103] Error compressing file: /tmp/log
[Err] [LogRecord.cc:534] Failed to compressed log file and resources to [/tmp/log.zip]

If I remember correctly, we were creating new numbered directories if the directory already existed?

The zip file is created as a sibling to the record path, i.e.:

/tmp/log
|-- home
|   `-- chapulina
|-- server_console.log
`-- state.tlog
/tmp/log.zip

This was a bit counter-intuitive to me, because I was expecting Gazebo not to create any files outside that directory. But maybe it's just me.

Also, keeping both the zip file and the original folders means every log takes even more space, with redundant information. Some things I'm wondering about:

  • Should we delete the directory after zipping it?

  • Should we make zipping optional?

  • Should we support playing back directly from the zip file?

I think we more fixes to the paths are needed. Try this:

  1. ign gazebo -v 4 -r log_record_resources.sdf --record-resources --record-path '/tmp/log'

content.raw:
I created a few checklist items to try to capture these.

> I'm seeing the log.zip file being created even if I'm not recording resources. Is this expected?

No, there should have been a flag check. Added in 9b84b5f.

> If I remember correctly, we were creating new numbered directories if the directory already existed?

I saw that this had been removed before this PR. In `default` branch, it still has this line:

```
logPath = common::uniqueDirectoryPath(logPath);
```

But it is no longer in `ign-gazebo2` branch. It existed in `ign-gazebo` [f9963d8](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/f9963d81807019ae75cadf7c8bcf7f2090f65691/src/systems/log/LogRecord.cc?at=ign-gazebo2#lines-184) but was removed in [22d7915](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/22d79157d28d5d2984f70f0128413998476d1565/src/systems/log/LogRecord.cc?at=ign-gazebo2#lines-165), where the behavior has been changed to overwrite existing directory, but that doesn’t seem to be implemented correctly right now. I think it just needs a remove of the existing directory and compressed file.

> The `zip` file is created as a sibling to the record path, i.e.:

So... yeah... the directory organization was an issue that got kind of tricky and I wasn't sure what's the best way. Right now it zips the whole directory purely becase `` `Zip()`` takes a directory only, so I could not give it multiple files \(the sub-directory, the `state.tlog` and the console file\). So it sits outside the directory it zips.

> Should we delete the directory after zipping it?

That was the original and most intuitive way I tried. There were problems with it, which I tried to describe in the last paragraph of the PR description. I think it’s cleaner to delete it, but we need to resolve the other directory problems, which comes down to whether we want to just overwrite things.

> Should we make zipping optional?

I don’t know the right answer to this. Zipping keeps the file smaller, but I don’t know how big the file will end up after 1 hour run. If zipping takes forever, then maybe people don’t want the program to run forever - they might want it to just terminate, and they can compress it themselves later.

> Should we support playing back directly from the zip file?

This is already implemented in `LogPlayback::ExtractStateAndResources()`. For context, the `log` directory is only kept because of the directory overwrite problem above. It is not needed; `log.zip` file alone should already be sufficient for playback.

> Instead of loading the logged mesh, the simulation prints these errors:

Does this have to do with the `model://` and `file://` differences? I still need to replace all `file` with `model`. I haven’t done that yet.
content.html:
I created a few checklist items to try to capture these.

I'm seeing the log.zip file being created even if I'm not recording resources. Is this expected?

No, there should have been a flag check. Added in 9b84b5f.

If I remember correctly, we were creating new numbered directories if the directory already existed?

I saw that this had been removed before this PR. In default branch, it still has this line:

logPath = common::uniqueDirectoryPath(logPath);

But it is no longer in ign-gazebo2 branch. It existed in ign-gazebo f9963d8 but was removed in 22d7915, where the behavior has been changed to overwrite existing directory, but that doesn’t seem to be implemented correctly right now. I think it just needs a remove of the existing directory and compressed file.

The zip file is created as a sibling to the record path, i.e.:

So... yeah... the directory organization was an issue that got kind of tricky and I wasn't sure what's the best way. Right now it zips the whole directory purely becase `Zip() takes a directory only, so I could not give it multiple files (the sub-directory, the state.tlog and the console file). So it sits outside the directory it zips.

Should we delete the directory after zipping it?

That was the original and most intuitive way I tried. There were problems with it, which I tried to describe in the last paragraph of the PR description. I think it’s cleaner to delete it, but we need to resolve the other directory problems, which comes down to whether we want to just overwrite things.

Should we make zipping optional?

I don’t know the right answer to this. Zipping keeps the file smaller, but I don’t know how big the file will end up after 1 hour run. If zipping takes forever, then maybe people don’t want the program to run forever - they might want it to just terminate, and they can compress it themselves later.

Should we support playing back directly from the zip file?

This is already implemented in LogPlayback::ExtractStateAndResources(). For context, the log directory is only kept because of the directory overwrite problem above. It is not needed; log.zip file alone should already be sufficient for playback.

Instead of loading the logged mesh, the simulation prints these errors:

Does this have to do with the model:// and file:// differences? I still need to replace all file with model. I haven’t done that yet.

content.raw:
> the behavior has been changed to overwrite existing directory

You're right, it was changed on pull request #413. I think the intended use case was when the user intentionally wants to overwrite, but I think it's also useful to support creating a new numbered directory.

> If zipping takes forever, then maybe people don’t want the program to run forever

That's a good point. How about adding a flag so the user can enable zipping. In case zipping is enabled, we delete the original directory in the end. So we never end up with both the zip and the dir. What do you think?

> Does this have to do with the model:// and file:// differences?

Yeah I think so.
content.html:
the behavior has been changed to overwrite existing directory

You're right, it was changed on pull request #413. I think the intended use case was when the user intentionally wants to overwrite, but I think it's also useful to support creating a new numbered directory.

If zipping takes forever, then maybe people don’t want the program to run forever

That's a good point. How about adding a flag so the user can enable zipping. In case zipping is enabled, we delete the original directory in the end. So we never end up with both the zip and the dir. What do you think?

Does this have to do with the model:// and file:// differences?

Yeah I think so.

content.raw:
Okay, sounds like 

* We should create an `--overwrite-existing` flag to force overwrite. If not provided, then create a new numbered directory.
* We should create a `--compress` flag to zip the file after recording is finished, then remove the original directory.

In the case of overwrite, everything is easy, the directory or the zip \(whichever exists\) will simply be removed at the beginning of the program, and written to.

In the case of creating a new numbered directory, we need to check both the directory and the zip file path, to see if either of them exists \(depending on whether `--compress` had been specified when they were created\). If either exists, the number for both the directory and the zip file \(if `--compress` is specified\) will use the new number.

That should be a more tidy solution to all the mess with directory and zips and overwrite errors…
content.html:
Okay, sounds like

  • We should create an --overwrite-existing flag to force overwrite. If not provided, then create a new numbered directory.
  • We should create a --compress flag to zip the file after recording is finished, then remove the original directory.

In the case of overwrite, everything is easy, the directory or the zip (whichever exists) will simply be removed at the beginning of the program, and written to.

In the case of creating a new numbered directory, we need to check both the directory and the zip file path, to see if either of them exists (depending on whether --compress had been specified when they were created). If either exists, the number for both the directory and the zip file (if --compress is specified) will use the new number.

That should be a more tidy solution to all the mess with directory and zips and overwrite errors…

content.raw: Sounds good to me! :thumbsup:
content.html: Sounds good to me!

content.raw:
The above items, other than the `model://` one, have been implemented as of 66f80e7.

Since now there is a `--compress` flag, a zip file will be created even if we’re not recording resources. This is to make the flag’s behavior clean.

Two general behaviors I’m unsure about:

1. If `--record` is specified, but no `--record-path` is specified, and a `<path></path>` is specified in the SDF LogRecord plugin, then ServerConfig creates a timestamped directory, instead of using the one in `<path></path>`. Is this desired?  
  This means if I run `$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --record`, and the SDF says `<path>/tmp/log</path>`, it will still record to a default timestamped directory `~/.ignition/gazebo/log/<timestamp>`.
2. This one is really weird. If `--record-path '/tmp/log'` is specified, even if I `rm /tmp/log -r` right before the run, for some reason, the directory is already created before it gets to the check of `common::exists(this->logPath)` inside the LogRecord plugin.  
  To reproduce:

    `$ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log' ... [Wrn] [LogRecord.cc:292] Log path already exists on disk! Existing files will be overwritten. [Msg] Overwriting existing path [/tmp/log] [Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog] ...`



    The “Overwriting…” line shouldn’t happen, because the directory shouldn’t exist yet.  
    But if I only specify the `<path>` in the SDF and don’t specify `--record-path`, then it only prints:



    `[Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]`



    which is correct.  
    Could it be that if both `<path>` and `--record-path` are specified, there are two LogRecord plugins running? I can’t find where that directory could have been created before the plugin does the check - [ServerConfig.cc](http://ServerConfig.cc) doesn’t create any directories.



‌
content.html:
The above items, other than the model:// one, have been implemented as of 66f80e7.

Since now there is a --compress flag, a zip file will be created even if we’re not recording resources. This is to make the flag’s behavior clean.

Two general behaviors I’m unsure about:

  1. If --record is specified, but no --record-path is specified, and a <path></path> is specified in the SDF LogRecord plugin, then ServerConfig creates a timestamped directory, instead of using the one in <path></path>. Is this desired?
    This means if I run $ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --record, and the SDF says <path>/tmp/log</path>, it will still record to a default timestamped directory ~/.ignition/gazebo/log/<timestamp>.

  2. This one is really weird. If --record-path '/tmp/log' is specified, even if I rm /tmp/log -r right before the run, for some reason, the directory is already created before it gets to the check of common::exists(this->logPath) inside the LogRecord plugin.
    To reproduce:

    $ ign gazebo -v 4 -r examples/worlds/log_record_resources.sdf --overwrite --record-path '/tmp/log' ... [Wrn] [LogRecord.cc:292] Log path already exists on disk! Existing files will be overwritten. [Msg] Overwriting existing path [/tmp/log] [Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog] ...

    The “Overwriting…” line shouldn’t happen, because the directory shouldn’t exist yet.
    But if I only specify the <path> in the SDF and don’t specify --record-path, then it only prints:

    [Msg] Recording to log file [/tmp/log/state.tlog]

    which is correct.
    Could it be that if both <path> and --record-path are specified, there are two LogRecord plugins running? I can’t find where that directory could have been created before the plugin does the check - ServerConfig.cc doesn’t create any directories.

‌

It looks like it's always being created [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/a5d9d4b4a0cf5905239ba07a1891495c97c2ec05/src/cmd/ign.cc#lines-67)
content.html:
If --record-path '/tmp/log' is specified, even if I rm /tmp/log -r right before the run, for some reason, the directory is already created before it gets to the check of common::exists(this->logPath) inside the LogRecord plugin

It looks like it's always being created here

content.html: We could move the logic of overwrite to ign.cc and don't modify recordPath inside LogRecord. What do you think?

content.raw:
Would it be possible to do this on `PreUpdate` or `PostUpdate`? This system usually runs alongside `Physics`, and physics should be the only system active during update.

If the `_ecm` can be `const`, I recommend you do this on `PostUpdate` so that it runs in parallel with other systems.
content.html:
Would it be possible to do this on PreUpdate or PostUpdate? This system usually runs alongside Physics, and physics should be the only system active during update.

If the _ecm can be const, I recommend you do this on PostUpdate so that it runs in parallel with other systems.

content.raw: Moved to PostUpdate in a0892c9
content.html: Moved to PostUpdate in a0892c9

content.raw:
I just realized this has been adding an attribute all along, when it should actually be adding an element. It's working because `_sdf->Get<std::string>("path")` checks both attributes and elements, but I think we should be consistent in case someone tries to access the elements in a different way.

The example world is using elements:

```
    <plugin
      filename="libignition-gazebo-log-system.so"
      name="ignition::gazebo::systems::LogRecord">
      <path>/tmp/log</path>
      <record_resources>0</record_resources>
      <overwrite>0</overwrite>
      <compress>0</compress>
    </plugin>
```

And the server is using attributes:

```
    <plugin
      filename="libignition-gazebo-log-system.so"
      name="ignition::gazebo::systems::LogRecord"
      path="/tmp/log"
      record_resources=false
      overwrite=false
      compress=false/>
```
content.html:
I just realized this has been adding an attribute all along, when it should actually be adding an element. It's working because _sdf->Get<std::string>("path") checks both attributes and elements, but I think we should be consistent in case someone tries to access the elements in a different way.

The example world is using elements:

    <plugin
      filename="libignition-gazebo-log-system.so"
      name="ignition::gazebo::systems::LogRecord">
      <path>/tmp/log</path>
      <record_resources>0</record_resources>
      <overwrite>0</overwrite>
      <compress>0</compress>
    </plugin>

And the server is using attributes:

    <plugin
      filename="libignition-gazebo-log-system.so"
      name="ignition::gazebo::systems::LogRecord"
      path="/tmp/log"
      record_resources=false
      overwrite=false
      compress=false/>

content.raw:
This may be causing issues on lines like this above: `sdf::ParamPtr pathParam = pluginElem->GetAttribute("path");`

Since the SDF files have been using elements, the server is probably always adding attributes.
content.html:
This may be causing issues on lines like this above: sdf::ParamPtr pathParam = pluginElem->GetAttribute("path");

Since the SDF files have been using elements, the server is probably always adding attributes.

content.raw: I'm not sure about separating the logic for the compressed file and the rest of the log, because this means they could end up with different names depending on the combination of flags and whether one exists but not the other.
content.html: I'm not sure about separating the logic for the compressed file and the rest of the log, because this means they could end up with different names depending on the combination of flags and whether one exists but not the other.

content.raw:
So… I had the logic together first, in the first block where the console log was initiated. Then I ran into this scenario:`/tmp/log` exists, because it was generated in a run without `--compress`; `/tmp/log(1).zip` exists, because it was generated in a run with `--compress`, so`/tmp/log(1)` doesn’t exist; then, `common::uniqueDirectoryPath` gives `/tmp/log(1)` as the path, which works for the path, but does not work for the zip file. So it needs to then check the zip `cmpPath` after generating the `recordPathMod`, generate a `common::uniqueFilePath`, and go back to generate a new `recordPathMod`. But as it does the first and second renaming, all the messages about this renaming will not be logged. So… I moved the `cmpDest` to after the `recordPathMod` has been finalized.  
That said, I do like that way better, which combines the check of `/tmp/log(1)` and `/tmp/log(1).zip` in the same if-statement, because that gives paths like `/tmp/log(2)` and `/tmp/log(2).zip`. Downside is some messages are not logged. The current way logs all messages, but gives names like `/tmp/log(1).zip(1)`.
content.html:
So… I had the logic together first, in the first block where the console log was initiated. Then I ran into this scenario:/tmp/log exists, because it was generated in a run without --compress; /tmp/log(1).zip exists, because it was generated in a run with --compress, so/tmp/log(1) doesn’t exist; then, common::uniqueDirectoryPath gives /tmp/log(1) as the path, which works for the path, but does not work for the zip file. So it needs to then check the zip cmpPath after generating the recordPathMod, generate a common::uniqueFilePath, and go back to generate a new recordPathMod. But as it does the first and second renaming, all the messages about this renaming will not be logged. So… I moved the cmpDest to after the recordPathMod has been finalized.
That said, I do like that way better, which combines the check of /tmp/log(1) and /tmp/log(1).zip in the same if-statement, because that gives paths like /tmp/log(2) and /tmp/log(2).zip. Downside is some messages are not logged. The current way logs all messages, but gives names like /tmp/log(1).zip(1).

content.raw: Ah I see, makes sense. I'm leaning towards losing a couple of log messages in favor of keeping the file names consistent. Names like `/tmp/log(1).zip(1)` are no good, we shouldn't mess with the extension :confused:
content.html: Ah I see, makes sense. I'm leaning towards losing a couple of log messages in favor of keeping the file names consistent. Names like /tmp/log(1).zip(1) are no good, we shouldn't mess with the extension

Nit: the 2 flags, `LogRecordCompress` and `LogRecordCompressPath` are a bit redundant. What happens if the user sets a path but not to compress, or the other way around?

We could even recalculate the compress path within `LogRecord` or only set the path and check whether to compress with `bool compress = !config.LogRecordCompressPath().empty();`
content.html:
Nit: the 2 flags, LogRecordCompress and LogRecordCompressPath are a bit redundant. What happens if the user sets a path but not to compress, or the other way around?

We could even recalculate the compress path within LogRecord or only set the path and check whether to compress with bool compress = !config.LogRecordCompressPath().empty();

content.raw:
I tried to handle backward compatibility in 7d8f060. Could you give it another spin?

Since we can’t tell what version of the plugin was used to record the log files, I simply check if the URI prepended with the playback path exists. If it doesn’t exist, then playback assumes that the file was recorded using an older version, and the playback log path is not prepended. In this case it just would leave the path alone as `~/.ignition/fuel/...`.
content.html:
I tried to handle backward compatibility in 7d8f060. Could you give it another spin?

Since we can’t tell what version of the plugin was used to record the log files, I simply check if the URI prepended with the playback path exists. If it doesn’t exist, then playback assumes that the file was recorded using an older version, and the playback log path is not prepended. In this case it just would leave the path alone as ~/.ignition/fuel/....

content.raw:
Hmm, I think I see why Addisu mentioned something about relative paths in the meeting. When I comment out the `Gazebo - relative paths` line, then the `fuel.sdf` works.

Inspecting the debug messages, I see that a mesh URI is printed simply as `meshes/gazebo.dae`, while the other is printed as `file:///home/master/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/nate/models/my_Backpack/2//meshes/Backpack.dae`. The `meshes/gazebo.dae` is the URI specified in the `model.sdf` in `Gazebo - relative paths`, while the absolute path is specified in `Backpack.dae`.

That mesh URI is obtained from `_ecm.EachNew()` and then passed to `addModelResource(meshUri)` to be stored. Currently, that function handles paths beginning with `model://`, `file://`, and `/`. With the relative path `meshes/gazebo.dae`, it doesn’t know what to prepend as the parent path in order to find the file, because that information isn’t available from the ECM… or is it? Can it be obtained somewhere?
content.html:
Hmm, I think I see why Addisu mentioned something about relative paths in the meeting. When I comment out the Gazebo - relative paths line, then the fuel.sdf works.

Inspecting the debug messages, I see that a mesh URI is printed simply as meshes/gazebo.dae, while the other is printed as file:///home/master/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/nate/models/my_Backpack/2//meshes/Backpack.dae. The meshes/gazebo.dae is the URI specified in the model.sdf in Gazebo - relative paths, while the absolute path is specified in Backpack.dae.

That mesh URI is obtained from _ecm.EachNew() and then passed to addModelResource(meshUri) to be stored. Currently, that function handles paths beginning with model://, file://, and /. With the relative path meshes/gazebo.dae, it doesn’t know what to prepend as the parent path in order to find the file, because that information isn’t available from the ECM… or is it? Can it be obtained somewhere?

content.raw: So, the plugin cannot know which path an SDF comes from, by the time the SDF element becomes a component in the ECM, right? That is when the recorder sees a relative path like `<uri>meshes/gazebo.dae</uri>`. By this point, the information of where the parent path of `meshes` is already lost. So the recorder doesn’t have the information to resolve that path.
content.html: So, the plugin cannot know which path an SDF comes from, by the time the SDF element becomes a component in the ECM, right? That is when the recorder sees a relative path like <uri>meshes/gazebo.dae</uri>. By this point, the information of where the parent path of meshes is already lost. So the recorder doesn’t have the information to resolve that path.

content.raw: There were some recent changes to sdformat and ign-gazebo that added support for relative URIs. [sdformat PR #558](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/558/) added `sdf::Mesh::FilePath`, which returns the absolute path of the sdf file containing `<mesh>` entry. This can be used with `ignition::gazebo::asFullPath` (added in ign-gazebo PR #433) to get the path of the mesh from the geometry component in the ECM. [Here's](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/src/default/src/rendering/SceneManager.cc#lines-338) an example usage.
content.html: There were some recent changes to sdformat and ign-gazebo that added support for relative URIs. sdformat PR #558 added sdf::Mesh::FilePath, which returns the absolute path of the sdf file containing <mesh> entry. This can be used with ignition::gazebo::asFullPath (added in ign-gazebo PR #433) to get the path of the mesh from the geometry component in the ECM. Here's an example usage.

content.raw:
This fixes the first issue for me:

~~~
diff -r 14b400a699f9 src/systems/log/LogPlayback.cc
--- a/src/systems/log/LogPlayback.cc    Tue Oct 22 13:49:56 2019 -0400
+++ b/src/systems/log/LogPlayback.cc    Mon Nov 25 17:10:53 2019 -0800
@@ -393,7 +393,7 @@
     }
 
     // Prepend log path to file path
-    std::string pathPrepended = filePrefix + common::joinPaths(this->logPath,
+    std::string pathPrepended = common::joinPaths(this->logPath,
       pathNoPrefix);
 
     // For backward compatibility. If prepended record path does not exist,
~~~

It looks like `common::exists` doesn't support paths starting with `file://`, so it thinks that the prepended path doesn't exist and tries to look at the original location.

It looks like `file://` was added on purpose though - do you think it's ok to remove it, @{mabelmzhang} ?
content.html:
This fixes the first issue for me:

diff -r 14b400a699f9 src/systems/log/LogPlayback.cc
--- a/src/systems/log/LogPlayback.cc    Tue Oct 22 13:49:56 2019 -0400
+++ b/src/systems/log/LogPlayback.cc    Mon Nov 25 17:10:53 2019 -0800
@@ -393,7 +393,7 @@
     }

     // Prepend log path to file path
-    std::string pathPrepended = filePrefix + common::joinPaths(this->logPath,
+    std::string pathPrepended = common::joinPaths(this->logPath,
       pathNoPrefix);

     // For backward compatibility. If prepended record path does not exist,

It looks like common::exists doesn't support paths starting with file://, so it thinks that the prepended path doesn't exist and tries to look at the original location.

It looks like file:// was added on purpose though - do you think it's ok to remove it, @Mabel Zhang ?

content.raw:
Some manual testing I did that worked great:

---

1. `ign gazebo -v 3 -r --record-resources --record-path /tmp/lala fuel.sdf`
1. Resources are recorded to `/tmp/lala/` together with other log files.
1. `rm -rf ~/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org`
1. `ign gazebo -v 3 -r -p /tmp/lala`
1. Resources show up correctly and are not downloaded again.

---

1. `ign gazebo -v 3 -r --record-resources --log-compress --record-path /tmp/lele fuel.sdf`
1. `/tmp/lele.zip` is recorded
1. `rm -rf ~/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org`
1. `ign gazebo -v 3 -r -p /tmp/lele.zip`
1. Resources show up correctly and are not downloaded again.

---
content.html:
Some manual testing I did that worked great:

  1. ign gazebo -v 3 -r --record-resources --record-path /tmp/lala fuel.sdf
  2. Resources are recorded to /tmp/lala/ together with other log files.
  3. rm -rf ~/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org
  4. ign gazebo -v 3 -r -p /tmp/lala
  5. Resources show up correctly and are not downloaded again.
  1. ign gazebo -v 3 -r --record-resources --log-compress --record-path /tmp/lele fuel.sdf
  2. /tmp/lele.zip is recorded
  3. rm -rf ~/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org
  4. ign gazebo -v 3 -r -p /tmp/lele.zip
  5. Resources show up correctly and are not downloaded again.
